Award.AwardTitle: Invariants of bordered 3-manifolds and contact structures in Floer homology, connections with Khovanov homology, and applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposed project involves studying geometric structures on 3- and 4-dimensional manifolds. Understanding these spaces and structures is central to understanding the shape of our macroscopic universe, and many of the theories the PI intends to study have applications and origins in physics. A major goal of the PI's proposal is to develop methods which might be used to unify several existing and important tools for studying 3- and 4-dimensional manifolds. Such a unification would likely reveal interesting connections between quite disparate fields of mathematics. The PI also plans to use some of these tools to study contact structures and knots in new ways. Both serve as probes by which to study 3- and 4-dimensional manifolds. Contact structures are also important in classical mechanics, thermodynamics, dynamical systems, and in the study of liquid crystals, while knot theory has found many recent applications in the study of DNA knotting. This proposal also contains several explicit directions for student research, at both undergraduate and graduate levels, and will support the PI's teaching and mentoring activities.

Over the last couple decades, Floer theory has revolutionized the study of the topology and geometry of smooth manifolds in dimensions 3 and 4. There are multiple distinct Floer theories for 3-manifolds defined using techniques from quite different branches of mathematics. Amazingly several of these theories appear to give the same information, indicating deep connections between fields like symplectic geometry and gauge theory. These connections have lead to beautiful results like Taubes' proof of the Weinstein conjecture. Despite remarkable progress in understanding these connections, one wonders whether there is a simpler, unifying explanation. Indeed, a fundamental open problem and a distant lodestar for the PI's proposal is to axiomatize Floer theory. One approach to this and to the related problem of computing Floer theories is to develop invariants of bordered 3-manifolds and a means of computing the invariant of a closed manifold from those of its pieces. The first such invariant was defined by Lipshitz, Ozsvath, and Szabo in Heegaard Floer homology. The PI's proposed bordered monopole Floer theory is novel in that it may provide methods for computing invariants of 4-manifolds as well (it is defined in the HM-from, "master" version, of monopole Floer homology), and can likely be ported to other Floer theories (an important ingredient for an approach to axiomatization). This proposal will support the further development of this theory. A closely related aspect of the proposal involves fleshing out connections between Floer theory and Khovanov homology, an invariant of links motivated by representation theory. Such connections were instrumental, for example, in Kronheimer and Mrowka's celebrated proof that Khovanov homology detects the unknot. Often these connections arise in the form of a spectral sequence from Khovanov homology and Floer thoery. A goal of this project is to better understand these spectral sequences. The PI proposes a means for combinatorially computing their terms and for proving that the sequences are functorial with respect to link cobordisms. The hope is to use these combinatorial methods and functoriality to better understand Floer invariants in dimensions 3 and 4. A final, complementary aspect of this proposal involves defining new invariants of contact structures. The PI has done so in recent work, using instanton and monopole Floer homology. An exciting future project is to use the instanton Floer invariant to uncover hitherto unexplored links between the Stein and symplectic fillings of a contact 3-manifold and its fundamental group.

POR.DRECONTENT:
I have completed the research funded by my NSF grant entitled "Invariants of bordered 3-manifolds and contact structures in Floer homology, connections with Khovanov homology, and applications". This research was broadly concerned with understanding 3- and 4-dimensional manifolds. These are the kinds of spaces which most resemble our spacetime universe. Understanding their properties and other structures—like knots—within them and developing tools for distinguishing them is a major subfield of mathematics these days. The author in his project successfully developed new Floer homology tools for understanding 3-manifolds and certain geometric objects called "contact structures" on them. He also developed new Khovanov homology tools for understanding knots within 3-manifolds. He also investigated the tantalizing and mysterious connections between Floer homology and Khovanov homology. These connections point to connections between seemingly disparate fields of mathematics and also open up vistas of questions for future research.

Over the course of this grant, I produced 5 research papers which have either been published or are submitted for publication, and have made substantial progress on two other research papers which will be submitted very soon. I have advised 3 graduate students (one graduated, now a postdoc at UGA, two in progress), 2 undergraduate senior theses, and 2 undergraduate research projects. I have given 6 invited seminar talks on my work and 11 invited conference talks. I have organized one international conference (the 12th William Rowan Hamilton Geometry and Topology Conference in Dublin, Ireland), and I founded the Boston Graduate Topology Seminar, which meets several times per year and unites graduate students, postdocs, and faculty from across the various Boston instututions for a Saturday microconference in topology.

I'll describe in more detail below my research output:

"On the functoriality of Khovanov-Floer theories", submitted to Advances in Mathematics (with Hedden and Lobb): in this paper we seek to provide a better explanation of a fascinating connection between Floer homology theories, which are tools for studying 3-manifolds, 4-manifolds, and knots that come from physics and rely on symplectic geometry and analysis, and Khovanov homology theories, which are tools for studying knots that come from the fields of algebra and representation theory. In particular, we develop the notion of a Khovanov-Floer theory and prove some structural properties of such theories. The connections between these theories often manifest in the form of what are called "spectral sequences". Basic questions are whether these spectral sequences are knot invariants and "functorial". We answer these questions for a host of Khovanov-Floer theories for the first time, using our new framework.


"Khovanov homology and knot Floer homology for pointed links", Journal of Knot Theory and its Ramifications, Tim Cochran Memorial Volume (with Levine and Sarkar): in this paper, we study a mysterious and seemingly intractable connection between Khovanov homology and knot Floer homology. It is conjectured that there is a spectral sequence relating these theories but such a sequence has proven very difficult to construct. One of the difficulties has to do with the differences between how Khovanov homology and knot Floer homology behave for links (knots made up from multiple curves). In this paper, we propose a different version of Khovanov homology for links which is more akin to knot Floer homology and make progress towards uniting these two objects.

 

"On the equivalence of contact invariants in sutured Floer homology theories", under revision at Geometry & Topology (with Sivek): in this paper we prove an equivalence between the invariant of contact structures on 3-manifold defined using Heegaard Floer homology and the invariant we defined using monopole Floer homology. The equivalence allows us to combine the advantages of each setting. For instance, we are able to prove that the Heegaard Floer contact invariant is well-defined without appealing to a somewhat controversial theorem relating contact structures and open books. We also provide computable obstructions to two Legendrian knots being "Legendrian concordant".

 

"Stein fillings and SU(2) representations", submitted to Geometry & Topology (with Sivek): in this paper we establish a brand new connection between properties of contact structures on a 3-manifold and a very different, basic object associated to the 3-manifold called the "fundamental group". 

 

"On the complexity of torus knot recognition", to appear in Transactions of the American Mathematical Society (with Sivek): a basic question concerns the difficulty in showing that two knots are distinct. Knots fall into 3 basic categories: torus knots, hyperbolic knots, and satellite knots. In this paper, we study the difficulty of deciding which category a given knot falls into.

 

"Khovanov homology detects the trefoils", preprint available (with Sivek): Kronheimer and Mrowka famously proved that Khovanov homology can tell whether a given knot is the "unknot", the simplest knot. In this paper, we prove that Khovanov homology can tell whether a given knot is a "trefoil", which is the next simplest knot.
